metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Compare the momentum of photons and of matter of the same wavelength including calculations using: p = h/λ

universal_momentum_wavelength.name: Universal Momentum-Wavelength Formula
universal_momentum_wavelength.correct: The formula p = h/λ applies universally to both photons and matter. Same wavelength means same momentum.

p = λ/h.fix: h is in the numerator, λ in the denominator: p = h/λ
p = λ/h.action: Check: bigger momentum should give smaller wavelength. Does your formula do that?

p = hλ.fix: p = h/λ means h DIVIDED BY λ.
p = hλ.action: Units check: (J·s)/m = kg·m/s. Does hλ give momentum units?

p = h + λ.error: Cannot add quantities with different units.
p = h + λ.fix: h has units J·s, λ has units m. They must be divided.
p = h + λ.action: Think about units. Addition only works for same units.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the mathematical relationship between p, h, and λ.
persistent.action: Write out p = h/λ five times. Then rearrange to get λ = h/p. Practice both forms.

photon_momentum_formula.name: Photon Momentum Formula
photon_momentum_formula.correct: For photons: p = E/c. Photon momentum equals energy divided by speed of light.

p = Ec.fix: p = E/c means E DIVIDED BY c.
p = Ec.action: Units check: J/(m/s) = J·s/m = kg·m/s. Does Ec give these units?

p = E/c².fix: The formula is p = E/c. One factor of c in denominator.
p = E/c².action: Don't confuse with E = mc². Different equation, different purpose.

p = c/E.fix: Energy E is in the numerator, speed c in the denominator.
p = c/E.action: Higher energy photons have more momentum. Does c/E show this?

persistent.gap: You're not clear on the photon energy-momentum relationship.
persistent.action: Memorise: E = pc for photons. Rearrange to p = E/c. Calculate p for three different photon energies.

photon_energy_momentum.name: Photon Energy-Momentum Relationship
photon_energy_momentum.correct: For photons: E = pc. Energy is directly proportional to momentum.

E = mc².error: That's rest mass energy. Photons have no rest mass.
E = mc².fix: Photons use E = pc because they have zero rest mass.
E = mc².action: Separate the formulas: photons (E = pc), rest mass (E = mc²).

E = ½pc.error: No factor of ½ for photons.
E = ½pc.fix: E = pc exactly. The ½ appears in kinetic energy of matter.
E = ½pc.action: Don't mix E = pc (photons) with KE = ½mv² (matter).

E = p/c.fix: E = pc means E = p × c.
E = p/c.action: Units: (kg·m/s)(m/s) = kg·m²/s² = J. Correct for energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing photon and matter energy formulas.
persistent.action: Make a table: Photons use E = pc. Matter uses KE = ½mv². Know both.

matter_momentum_formula.name: Matter Momentum Formula
matter_momentum_formula.correct: For matter: p = mv. Classical momentum equals mass times velocity.

p = m/v.fix: p = mv means mass TIMES velocity.
p = m/v.action: More velocity = more momentum. Does m/v show this?

p = ½mv.error: No factor of ½ in momentum.
p = ½mv.fix: p = mv. The ½ appears in kinetic energy: KE = ½mv².
p = ½mv.action: Don't confuse momentum (p = mv) with energy (KE = ½mv²).

p = mv².error: Only one factor of v in momentum.
p = mv².fix: p = mv. Not v². Kinetic energy has v² but momentum doesn't.
p = mv².action: Units: kg·m/s. Does mv² give these units?

persistent.gap: You're confusing momentum and kinetic energy formulas.
persistent.action: Memorise: p = mv, KE = ½mv². Note which has the square.

momentum_from_kinetic_energy.name: Momentum from Kinetic Energy
momentum_from_kinetic_energy.correct: For matter with kinetic energy: p = √(2mKE). Derived from KE = p²/2m.

p = 2mKE.fix: p = √(2mKE). The square root is essential.
p = 2mKE.action: Derive from KE = ½mv². Substitute p = mv to get KE = p²/2m, then solve for p.

p = √(mKE).fix: p = √(2mKE). The 2 comes from KE = p²/2m.
p = √(mKE).action: Start from KE = p²/2m. Rearrange to p² = 2mKE, then p = √(2mKE).

p = √(mKE/2).error: The 2 should be in the numerator, not denominator.
p = √(mKE/2).fix: p = √(2mKE) where 2m is multiplied by KE.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the energy-momentum relationship for matter.
persistent.action: Derive p = √(2mKE) from first principles: KE = ½mv², p = mv. Practice the algebra.

same_wavelength_same_momentum.name: Same Wavelength Means Same Momentum
same_wavelength_same_momentum.correct: If photons and matter have the same wavelength, they must have the same momentum (p = h/λ applies to both).

same energy.error: Same wavelength means same momentum, not same energy.
same energy.fix: Energy formulas differ: E = pc (photons) vs KE = p²/2m (matter).
same energy.action: Calculate: if p is the same but E = pc and KE = p²/2m, are energies equal?

same velocity.error: Velocity is unrelated. Photons always travel at c.
same velocity.fix: Photons travel at c regardless of wavelength. Momentum is what matches.
same velocity.action: Photon speed is fixed at c. Matter velocity varies.

same mass.error: Mass is completely different. Photons have no mass.
same mass.fix: Photons are massless, matter has mass. Momentum unifies them.
same mass.action: p = h/λ works for BOTH, regardless of mass.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what p = h/λ tells us about photon-matter comparison.
persistent.action: Key insight: wavelength determines momentum universally. Energy depends on particle type.

photon_no_mass.name: Photon Has No Rest Mass
photon_no_mass.correct: Photons have zero rest mass but still carry momentum via p = E/c = h/λ.

small mass.error: Photons have exactly zero mass, not 'small' mass.
small mass.fix: m = 0 for photons. Their momentum comes from E = pc, not p = mv.
small mass.action: If photons had mass, they couldn't travel at c.

mass from energy.error: E = mc² gives equivalent mass, not rest mass.
mass from energy.fix: Photons have relativistic energy but zero rest mass.
mass from energy.action: Don't confuse 'energy equivalent' with actual rest mass.

momentum requires mass.error: Classical thinking. Quantum objects can have momentum without mass.
momentum requires mass.fix: p = mv only works for matter. Photons use p = h/λ or p = E/c.
momentum requires mass.action: Solar sails prove photon momentum. They push the sail.

persistent.gap: You're applying classical momentum concepts to quantum particles.
persistent.action: Accept: photons have p = h/λ despite m = 0. This is verified experimentally.

diffraction_pattern_comparison.name: Diffraction Pattern Comparison
diffraction_pattern_comparison.correct: Identical diffraction pattern spacing means identical wavelengths, which means identical momentums.

same energy means same pattern.error: Pattern depends on wavelength, not energy.
same energy means same pattern.fix: Diffraction is determined by λ/w ratio. Same λ gives same pattern.
same energy means same pattern.action: 5000 eV electrons and 5000 eV photons have DIFFERENT wavelengths and patterns.

pattern depends on particle type.error: Diffraction depends on wavelength only, not whether it's photon or matter.
pattern depends on particle type.fix: Same wavelength = same pattern, regardless of particle type.
pattern depends on particle type.action: This is why electrons can replace X-rays in diffraction experiments.

different speeds mean different patterns.error: Speed doesn't directly determine pattern; wavelength does.
different speeds mean different patterns.fix: Photons at c and slow electrons can have the same wavelength.
different speeds mean different patterns.action: Focus on wavelength when comparing diffraction.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what determines diffraction pattern spacing.
persistent.action: Rule: diffraction pattern ∝ λ/w. Compare wavelengths, not energies or speeds.

different_energies_same_momentum.name: Different Energies, Same Momentum
different_energies_same_momentum.correct: Photons and matter with the same momentum have different energies because their energy-momentum relationships differ.

same momentum means same energy.error: Energy formulas are different for photons and matter.
same momentum means same energy.fix: Photon: E = pc. Matter: KE = p²/2m. Same p gives different E.
same momentum means same energy.action: Calculate both energies for p = 2×10⁻²⁴ kg·m/s. Compare.

photons have more energy.error: Depends on the momentum value. Can't generalise.
photons have more energy.fix: Compare specific cases. Sometimes photon energy is higher, sometimes lower.
photons have more energy.action: Work through the VCAA exam example: 5000 eV electrons vs X-rays.

matter always has more energy.error: Not true. Depends on mass and momentum.
matter always has more energy.fix: Light electrons might have less KE than a photon with same momentum.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why same momentum gives different energies.
persistent.action: Master both formulas: E_photon = pc and KE = p²/2m. Calculate examples.

planck_constant_value.name: Planck's Constant
planck_constant_value.correct: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s. Used in both photon and matter wavelength calculations.

6.63 × 10⁻²⁷ J·s.error: Wrong exponent. Off by 7 orders of magnitude.

6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.fix: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s in SI. In eV·s it's 4.14 × 10⁻¹⁵.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.action: Use J·s unless the question specifies eV.

1.06 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s.action: p = h/λ uses h, not ℏ. Know the difference.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise Planck's constant correctly.
persistent.action: Flashcard: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s. Review until automatic.

speed_of_light_value.name: Speed of Light
speed_of_light_value.correct: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. Used in photon momentum calculations: p = E/c.

3.0 × 10⁵ m/s.error: Wrong exponent. Speed of sound, not light.

3.0 × 10¹⁰ m/s.action: Nothing travels faster than c. 10¹⁰ would be 100× too fast.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the speed of light correctly.
persistent.action: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. Write it 10 times. Use it in calculations.

electron_mass_value.name: Electron Mass
electron_mass_value.correct: Electron mass is 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg. Used in matter momentum calculations.

9.1 × 10⁻²⁸ kg.error: Exponent wrong by 3. That's closer to proton mass.
9.1 × 10⁻²⁸ kg.fix: Electron mass is 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg. Much lighter than protons.

1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ kg.action: Different quantities, different values. Know both.

persistent.gap: You're confusing electron mass with other constants.
persistent.action: Make a table: m_e = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg, q_e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C. Memorise both.

universal_formula.title: The Universal Momentum-Wavelength Relationship
universal_formula.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how momentum and wavelength are related.

sentences.text: The relationship p = {{d1}} applies universally to both photons and matter, meaning that momentum is {{d2}} to wavelength.

d1.tooltip: Think about which quantity is in the numerator

d2.tooltip: As momentum increases, what happens to wavelength?

sentences.text: In the formula p = h/λ, h represents {{d3}} with a value of {{d4}}, while λ represents the {{d5}} of the particle or wave.

d3.tooltip: The fundamental quantum constant named after Max Planck

d4.tooltip: SI units with the correct exponent

d5.tooltip: Greek letter lambda represents what wave property?

sentences.text: If a photon and an electron have the {{d6}} wavelength, then according to p = h/λ, they must have the {{d7}} momentum.

d6.tooltip: The formula applies equally to both

d7.tooltip: What does identical wavelength imply for momentum?

photon_momentum.title: Momentum of Massless Photons
photon_momentum.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show how photon momentum is calculated despite photons having no mass.

sentences.text: Although photons have {{d1}} rest mass, experiments such as {{d2}} demonstrate that they possess momentum.

d2.tooltip: Spacecraft that use light pressure for propulsion

sentences.text: For photons, the relationship between energy and momentum is {{d3}}, where c is the {{d4}} with a value of {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: Energy equals momentum times what constant?

sentences.text: Rearranging E = pc gives {{d6}} for photon momentum, which can also be written as p = h/λ.

matter_momentum.title: Momentum of Matter Particles
matter_momentum.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about calculating momentum for particles with mass.

sentences.text: For matter particles like electrons, the classical momentum formula is p = {{d1}}, where m is mass and v is velocity.
An electron has a mass of {{d2}}. When an electron has kinetic energy, its momentum can also be calculated using {{d3}}.
The key difference is that matter uses {{d4}} while photons use {{d5}} to find momentum from energy.

d4.tooltip: Formula involving mass and kinetic energy

comparing_patterns.title: Comparing Diffraction Patterns
comparing_patterns.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about how diffraction patterns reveal particle properties.

sentences.text: When matter and photons with the {{d1}} wavelength pass through identical gaps, they produce diffraction patterns with {{d2}} spacing.

d1.tooltip: What wavelength condition gives matching patterns?

d2.tooltip: Same wavelength means same pattern spacing

sentences.text: If electrons and X-rays produce patterns with the same fringe spacing, this indicates they have the same {{d3}} and therefore the same {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Diffraction pattern depends on what property?

d4.tooltip: Same λ means same what via p = h/λ?

sentences.text: However, particles with the same momentum will generally have {{d5}} energies because the energy formulas are {{d6}} for photons and matter.

d6.tooltip: Photon and matter energy formulas are not the same

universal_formula.title: Applying the Momentum-Wavelength Relationship
universal_formula.instructions: Apply your understanding of p = h/λ to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: To find the momentum of any particle from its wavelength, use the formula {{d1}}. This is remarkable because it works for {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: What types of particles does this apply to?

sentences.text: When wavelength decreases, momentum {{d3}} because they are related by an {{d4}} relationship.

d3.tooltip: If λ is in the denominator, smaller λ means...?

d4.tooltip: Type of proportionality when one is in denominator

sentences.text: A photon with wavelength 500 nm and an electron with wavelength 500 nm would have {{d5}} momentum values, calculated as p = {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Same wavelength, same formula, same result

d6.tooltip: The calculation is the same for both

photon_momentum.title: Calculating Photon Momentum in Practice
photon_momentum.instructions: Apply photon momentum formulas to solve problems.

sentences.text: Given a photon with energy E, its momentum is found using {{d1}}. For example, if E = 6.0 × 10⁻¹⁶ J, then p = E/c = 6.0 × 10⁻¹⁶ / (3.0 × 10⁸) = {{d2}}.
The photon wavelength can be found from momentum using λ = {{d3}}. Substituting h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ and p = 2.0 × 10⁻²⁴ gives λ = {{d4}}.
Photon momentum enables technologies like {{d5}}, which use light pressure to accelerate spacecraft by {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Uses reflection of sunlight for propulsion

d6.tooltip: Photons carry momentum which they transfer on reflection

matter_momentum.title: Calculating Matter Momentum in Practice
matter_momentum.instructions: Apply momentum formulas for particles with mass.

sentences.text: An electron with kinetic energy KE = 5000 eV must first be converted to Joules: KE = 5000 × {{d1}} = 8.0 × 10⁻¹⁶ J.

d1.tooltip: Conversion factor from eV to Joules

sentences.text: To find this electron's momentum, use p = {{d2}}. With m = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg and KE = 8.0 × 10⁻¹⁶ J, this gives p = {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: Formula relating momentum to kinetic energy

sentences.text: Alternatively, if the electron speed is v = 2.2 × 10⁶ m/s, momentum is p = mv = {{d4}} × 2.2 × 10⁶ = {{d5}}.

comparing_patterns.title: Interpreting Diffraction Pattern Comparisons
comparing_patterns.instructions: Apply your understanding to compare photon and electron diffraction.

sentences.text: When comparing electron and X-ray diffraction, if the fringe spacing is {{d1}}, the particles have the same {{d2}} regardless of their type.

d1.tooltip: What pattern property indicates same wavelength?

sentences.text: An electron with momentum 2.5 × 10⁻²³ kg·m/s produces the same pattern as an X-ray with momentum {{d3}} kg·m/s, because same momentum means same {{d4}}.
However, their energies differ: the X-ray energy is E = pc = {{d5}} J, while the electron KE = p²/2m will be a {{d6}} value.

d6.tooltip: Different energy formulas give different results

universal_formula.title: Mastering the Momentum-Wavelength Connection
universal_formula.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of the universal p = h/λ relationship.

sentences.text: The universality of p = h/λ means that the property determining diffraction behavior is {{d1}}, not whether the particle has {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Same momentum means same wavelength means same diffraction

d2.tooltip: The formula works for both massive and massless particles

sentences.text: A common misconception is that particles with the same {{d3}} will produce the same diffraction pattern. This is wrong because energy-wavelength relationships {{d4}} between photons and matter.

d3.tooltip: What property does NOT determine pattern?

sentences.text: The VCE exam often asks: 5000 eV electrons and 5000 eV photons have {{d5}} wavelengths. The answer is {{d6}} because same energy does not mean same momentum.

d6.tooltip: Calculate p for each using their respective formulas

photon_momentum.title: Advanced Photon Momentum Applications
photon_momentum.instructions: Apply photon momentum to complex scenarios.

sentences.text: The relationship between photon wavelength and momentum can be written as {{d1}} or equivalently as {{d2}}, showing that shorter wavelength photons carry more momentum.
Combining E = pc and E = hc/λ confirms that photon momentum is {{d3}}. This is consistent because E = hf and c = fλ, so E = hc/λ = pc gives p = {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: The consistent result from any derivation

sentences.text: When n photons reflect off a surface, each transfers momentum {{d5}}, so the total force depends on the {{d6}} of photons per second.

d6.tooltip: More photons means more momentum transfer

matter_momentum.title: Advanced Matter Momentum Applications
matter_momentum.instructions: Apply matter momentum to complex scenarios.

sentences.text: The formulas p = mv and p = √(2mKE) are equivalent because {{d1}} can be rearranged to give KE = p²/2m, then solving for p gives {{d2}}.
To produce the same diffraction pattern as a photon of wavelength λ, an electron must have de Broglie wavelength {{d3}}, requiring momentum p = {{d4}}.
From p = h/λ, the required electron velocity is v = p/m = {{d5}}. This shows that electrons with {{d6}} wavelengths must travel faster.

d5.tooltip: Substitute p = h/λ into v = p/m

d6.tooltip: Inverse relationship between λ and v

comparing_patterns.title: Complete Pattern Comparison Analysis
comparing_patterns.instructions: Synthesize all concepts for complete diffraction analysis.

sentences.text: The key insight for comparing photons and matter is: same {{d1}} → same wavelength → same pattern. But same energy gives {{d2}} patterns because energy-momentum relationships differ.

d1.tooltip: What quantity unifies photons and matter?

d2.tooltip: Same energy does NOT mean same momentum

sentences.text: Given electrons with momentum 2.0 × 10⁻²⁴ kg·m/s: X-ray energy for same pattern = pc = {{d3}} J. Electron KE = p²/2m = {{d4}} J. These are clearly {{d5}}.
This demonstrates why comparing {{d6}} is more useful than comparing energies when analyzing diffraction. The formula p = h/λ applies {{d7}} to both particle types.
